EDDIE
(fidgeting with his collar)
You sure these BB guns gonna do the trick? I mean, what if somebody in there's packin' real heat?

MARCUS
(sighs)
For the fifteenth time, Eddie, nobody's gonna know they ain't real. That's the whole goddamn point. They look real, we act real, everybody believes they're real. We ain't there to shoot nobody. We're there to scare 'em.

EDDIE
I know, I know. Just... first-time jitters, man.

MARCUS
Well, un-jitter yourself. Nine minutes 'til showtime.

*Marcus reaches into the backseat, pulls forward a duffel bag.*

Run it down for me again. From the top.

(rolling his eyes)

Right, right.

EDDIE
(nodding)

MARCUS
And what do you say if someone does?

EDDIE
"Everybody be cool, this is a robbery! Anyone moves and they're gettin' a face full of lead!"

MARCUS
(wincing)

Got it.

(pulling out gloves)
Gloves go on now. And these tennis shoes are crucial - can't leave no distinctive footprints. We got exactly three minutes inside. Not four, not five. Three. I empty the tills, you keep watch.

(sharp)
No vault! What'd we agree? Small bills, quick in, quick out. We ain't there to make history, just make rent.

EDDIE

Where Lenny BETTER be waitin'. Three blocks east, alley behind the laundromat. We ditch these clothes, ditch the BB guns, change into the work uniforms.

# Interrogation Room

The harsh fluorescent light buzzed overhead in the small interrogation room. Detective Johnson slapped a manila folder down on the metal table between them, the sound echoing off the concrete walls.

"You know why you're here, Don," Johnson said, his voice calm but edged with steel. He remained standing while Don sat comfortably in the metal chair, looking more like he was waiting for a business lunch than facing serious allegations.

"I assume it has something to do with my taxes?" Don replied, straightening his expensive tie. "Though I can't imagine why. My accountants are very thorough."

Johnson flipped open the folder, revealing bank statements and transaction records. "Thorough at hiding money, you mean." He pulled out a document and slid it across the table. "Cayman Islands. Panama. Singapore. You've been busy."

Don barely glanced at the paper. "I have international business interests. That's hardly a crime."

"Let me be clear," Johnson said, placing both palms on the table and leaning forward. "We've tracked seventeen separate transactions where proceeds from AutoEmpire sales never touched American soil. Millions in profits that mysteriously disappeared from your company's books only to reappear in accounts held by shell corporations."

Don's smile remained fixed. "Detective, I'm a businessman. Tax efficiency is part of running a successful enterprise."

"Tax efficiency?" Johnson laughed without humor. "Is that what we're calling fraud these days?" He pulled out another document. "Your customers paid taxes when they bought those cars. Your employees paid taxes on their salaries. But you? You decided the rules didn't apply to you."

"I follow the letter of the law," Don said, his composure finally showing a crack.

"The letter, maybe. Not the spirit." Johnson sat down across from him. "Here's what happens next. We've frozen those offshore accounts. The IRS has been building this case for two years. We have witness testimony from three former accountants at your firm."

For the first time, Don's expression faltered.

"You thought you were smarter than everyone else," Johnson continued. "That's always the mistake. It's not about being smart, Don. It's about thinking you're above the system that everyone else follows."

Don leaned forward, voice lower. "You have no idea what it takes to build something from nothing. The government takes and takes—"

"Save it," Johnson interrupted. "Tell it to the judge. Or better yet, tell it to the honest business owners who competed with you while actually paying their fair share."

He gathered the documents back into the folder. "Your lawyer's waiting outside. You're going to need a good one."
